Comments_List: I learned many different lab techniques and learned how to indepdently carry out many different experiments and understand its relevance on a larger more conceptual scale.

An all rounded experience of academic research, from conception of project, lab work, to presenting results in multiple media.

I really appreciated the fact that I could do research for a class. It made committing time to a lab feel less daunting and it also let me analyze data during a scheduled time instead of squeezing that in at the last minute.

I loved doing research at the Yale School of Medicine! I learned a lot of new laboratory techniques, and carried out my PI's project as well as did several experiments on my own out of curiosity. Overall, this course MCDB 486 (which is necessary if you want the B.S., or MCDB 496 if you're doing the Intensive one), is quite informational and you will form a bond with your PI and learn so much.

Reasearch has honestly been the best decision I made at Yale. I loved my lab and I think this is a great way to fulfill the thesis requirement. I learned how to be independent, understand science in hands on way, explain it to my peers and troubleshoot in an effective way.

This was fine. My main critique was that we had to make a poster and there was no funding available from the department. On top of that we also had to write a paper and a present a PowerPoint. Personally, I felt that the poster was super unnecessary and led to a large disparity in what students were able to do due to funding restrictions. This disparity was super clear at the poster symposium and thought it was pretty unfair.

Though actual contact with the department or instructors was sparse until the final presentations, I very much welcomed this style. I have two points of suggestion:
I wished there was a better leverage of the fact that we are conducting research at the same time for the major. Some sort of social platform like piazza, a discussion forum, or a facebook group could potentially let people discuss about their experiences and maybe even help each other out. The collaborative dimension of research was the one thing lacking from the whole experience.
While it is very reasonable for there to be no funding for poster printing, I envision that the department could strike an agreement with tyco or docuprintnow etc. to ask for a discount for MCDB students, and in return encourage MCDB students to use that printing shop. It wouldn't incur additional cost to the deot but still alleviate the cost of posters for students and also give them a reliable shop to go for.

Everything depends on your faculty PI, and it might be nice to have more resources available as students look for labs, or even doing this earlier in the Yale career would be good.

Strengths - the course made good attempts to be designed to give students a real-world experience in lab research. The course syllabus made it clear that mentors and PIs were supposed to work closely with the student and give the student a lot of support.

Weaknesses - while the structure was good, the execution was poor. The expectations for what the instructors had set for the course and what my PI and mentor expected from me were very, very different. The course syllabus expected 10-12 hrs of work per week in lab; in reality I ended up working closer to 20 hrs/wk (25+ at the worst of times). There was a large emphasis on only what my output could be in lab and whether I could represent the lab well, which felt like a lot of pressure given my small beginning skill set and my limited time that I could put into lab as an undergrad. Additionally, I was stressed because I felt I did not know where to turn when I needed help. In particular, I was struggling to execute a protocol that had never been demonstrated to me and had already been told would be difficult. I wanted to turn to my PI and mentor for help, but in a previous conversation, my PI told me explicitly that I was a burden to the lab, a waste of their time and money, and that they were being generous by giving me a chance to be there. This left me unsure whether I could continue to ask them for support. I felt nervous asking my PI and mentor for feedback on my presentation, poster, and paper, although it was clearly outlined in the syllabus that I was supposed to do so. Ultimately, my mentor did give me very constructive feedback for my presentation, but neither responded to emails asking for feedback on my poster and paper.

I am not trying to point fingers and accuse one party for blame, but I hope this problem could be avoided for future undergrads by making it clear what the expectations are for both parties. I think in my case, a large reason for the problem was due to a misunderstanding in what the syllabus expected, and what my PI and mentor expected. Because they should also have read the syllabus and signed a contract, I'm not sure how this disconnect became so vast, but I think they based what my performance should be on what previous undergrads had done in lab. These previous undergrads had all done the intensive course (which does expect ~20hrs/wk of work) and had aimed to go to grad school for research, which was different from my situation. I also wished for a better way to communicate to my PI and mentor what I needed from them in terms of feedback and support. I felt very blindsided by my PI's comments on my performance because my mentor had only ever given me positive feedback. When the protocol wasn't working, my mentor made it sound to me that it was only to be expected because it was so difficult, whereas my PI interpreted this as laziness and carelessness on my part. While laying out the need for support and feedback at the start of the year may have been the better approach, this also felt difficult to me because I was very intimidated, and my PI had made it clear to me when I first started working there that lab exists in a hierarchy, of which undergrads are the bottom. This resulted in a very poor experience for me, although it may be reflective of the true working world where your employer only cares about your work performance.

The experience that you will have is highly dependent on the lab you find yourself in and the research mentor who is guiding you. Almost everyone that I have met in the MCDB faculty has been extremely inviting and a pleasure to interact with so the odds are in your favor. But it would definitely benefit you in the long run to try and find a lab that you feel comfortable in and think you would enjoy spending time in. This arguably more important than the actual research you will be doing. You are going to be spending a lot of time on your topic, so you will become invested in it no matter what it is. You want to be able to enjoy the time in lab you spend on working.

It's basically unavoidable if you want to graduate with a B.S. in MCDB. Since you have to take it, I can only advise you to be very, VERY careful when selecting which lab you work for. The critical thing is not just to choose a research topic you're interested in, but also to find a PI and mentor who actually want to mentor you. Find someone who actually enjoys working with undergrads and wants to see you grow because they care about you and your personal growth, not just as how much of an asset you'll be to their lab. Also, make sure your lab isn't falling apart and has enough money to sustain taking on another undergrad. Having equipment break down or working in a dirty space is not only unpleasant but can actually be quite unsafe. A lab that is strapped for funds and in such a stressful environment will inevitably filter that stress down to you, and this is NOT a working environment you want to be in!
I would not but every MCDB BS Major has no choice so it doesn't really matter.
